head.title: At the Mall, Shopping and Darwinism

hedline.hl1: At the Mall, Shopping and Darwinism

abstract.p: Ann Axelrod letter suggests a Survivor-type television show based on the shopping mall experience; cartoon

block.p: In light of the fascination with the new voyeuristic television shows (editorial, June 4), I'd like to propose other programming opportunities that the public, and especially the young viewers whom networks covet, can relate to. One suggestion is ''Shopping Survivors,'' a show that tests the everyday social, shopping and, yes, survival skills of the participants.

In light of the fascination with the new voyeuristic television shows (editorial, June 4), I'd like to propose other programming opportunities that the public, and especially the young viewers whom networks covet, can relate to. One suggestion is ''Shopping Survivors,'' a show that tests the everyday social, shopping and, yes, survival skills of the participants.

After extensive screening, two teams gather in a mall for a three-day shopping competition and survival ''contest.'' The teams must perform tasks like finding sneakers that retail for less than $95, identifying the names of perfumes on fragrance sample cards and eating meals with less than 500 grams of fat.
Each day the two teams compete in a grueling cooperative event like dressing the whole team in designer clothing that does not feature obvious logos.

The winners receive a new credit card with an additional $5,000 spending limit that allows the team to stay in the mall for additional days. The losers must vote out a team member whose fashion sense they find the most objectionable. Now there's a reality show that I can really relate to!
ANN AXELROD Port Washington, N.Y., June 6, 2000
